content: The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007, also known as the "Gas Price Relief Act," temporarily suspends motor fuel taxes. The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007 temporarily suspends motor fuel taxes by setting the rates of tax to zero during the suspension period. This includes taxes on gasoline, diesel fuel, kerosene, special motor fuels, compressed natural gas, additional taxes for the Leaking Underground Storage Tank Trust Fund, and certain alcohol fuels. The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007 suspends motor fuel taxes, including taxes on gasoline, diesel fuel, kerosene, special motor fuels, compressed natural gas, additional taxes for the Leaking Underground Storage Tank Trust Fund, and certain alcohol fuels. Exceptions include fuel used in trains or motorboats and gasoline or kerosene used for aviation. The suspension period lasts from the enactment of the subsection to the end of the first 6 consecutive months thereafter. The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007 suspends motor fuel taxes for 6 consecutive months if the national average price of unleaded regular gasoline is less than $3.00 per gallon. Any reduction in tax rates will result in an equal amount being appropriated to the trust fund. The amendments made by this section will take effect upon the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. REPEAL OF EXPENSING FOR CERTAIN REFINERIES. The repeal of Section 179C of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is accompanied by technical amendments to various sections of the Code. This includes removing references to Section 179C in Section 1245(a), Section 263(a)(1), and Section 312(k)(3)(B). Additionally, the table of sections for part VI of subchapter B of chapter 1 is updated to reflect the repeal of Section 179C. The repeal of Section 179C of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 results in the transfer of equivalent tax liabilities to the Highway Trust Fund. The appropriated amounts will be based on estimates made by the Secretary of the Treasury, with adjustments made as necessary. These amendments apply to property placed in service after the enactment date. The amendments apply to property placed in service after the enactment date. SEC. 4. FLOOR STOCK REFUNDS. Floor stock refunds allow for a credit or refund to be issued to the taxpayer for excess tax paid on liquid held by a dealer before the enactment of the Act, intended for sale and not yet used. Claims for credit or refund must be filed within 6 months of the Act's enactment. The Act allows for a credit or refund to be issued to the taxpayer for excess tax paid on liquid held by a dealer before the enactment of the Act. Claims must be filed within 3 months, and no credit or refund is allowed for liquid in retail stocks. Definitions for "dealer" and "held by a dealer" are provided. The term "dealer" and "held by a dealer" are defined as per section 6412 of the Code, with "dealer" including a producer. Rules similar to subsections (b) and (c) of section 6412 of the Code apply to this section. SEC. 5. FLOOR STOCKS TAX. Imposition of Tax: A floor stocks tax is imposed on taxable liquid held on the floor stocks tax date, calculated as the excess of the tax that would be imposed under the Internal Revenue Code if the taxable event occurred on that date. Liability and payment methods are specified, with the tax due within 6 months of the floor stocks tax date. The floor stocks tax is due within 6 months after the floor stocks tax date. Definitions include what constitutes being "held by a person," the meaning of "taxable liquid," the definition of "floor stocks tax date," and who the "Secretary" refers to. There is an exception for exempt uses from the tax imposed. The tax imposed on taxable liquid has exceptions for exempt uses, fuel held in vehicle tanks, and certain amounts of fuel held on the floor stocks tax date. No tax is imposed on liquid held in vehicle tanks or if the aggregate amount held does not exceed 2,000 gallons. For tax purposes, certain information must be provided to the Secretary as required. Fuel exempt from tax is not considered. Controlled groups are treated as one person, following specific criteria. The provision allows for the substitution of "more than 50 percent" for "at least 80 percent" in certain subsections. Similar principles apply to nonincorporated persons under common control. Other laws applicable to taxes imposed by chapters 31 or 32 also apply to floor stock taxes imposed in the same manner. The Federal Trade Commission will monitor gasoline prices in the US, determining the national average price of unleaded regular gasoline monthly. Reports will be submitted to Congress and made available to the public online. SEC. 7. COMMISSION ON GAS PRICE RELIEF. Establishment of a Commission on Gas Price Relief by the Speaker of the House of Representatives within three months of the Act's enactment. The Commission will study the causes of high oil prices and submit a report to the House within a year. Membership includes 9 Members, with the Chairman of the Committee on Ways and Means as an ex officio member. The Commission on Gas Price Relief, established by the Speaker of the House of Representatives, consists of 9 members including the Chairmen of the Committee on Ways and Means and Energy and Commerce as co-chairs. Members are appointed by the Speaker and Chairmen, with specific party affiliations requirements.
